        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        Just because cultures have accepted practices, does not make those bandwagon practices ethical; whether it's cutting in line, slavery, rape, war, ETC.

        Law ≠ Ethics

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

        Thread:
        Week 5 Tutorial Qs. Probably too late
        Post:
        RE: Week 5 Tutorial Qs. Probably too late
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        14 April 2017 03:54
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello David,

        Q1

        You aren't supposed to be anonymous on social media platforms.

        Q3

        It's fair if it's supported by informed consent. Expressing your opinion about your new job, like how much you hate it, could be damaging to the reputation of the business if it goes viral; policing social media can help maintain a certain image for the business. Presentation is important for the success of the business, and your career depends the success of the business.

        You may think the highly intelligent person is doing something silly, but they probably think the same of you.

        Q4

        Andy isn't necessarily in the IT industry; non-IT students aren't necessarily made aware of the situation/risks/ETC.

        Q5,6

        : Claiming to be the author when you aren't the author, is a lie.
        : Lying is unethical.
        ∴ Hiring ghosts is unethical.
        … I'm not sure about being a ghost; but if the ghost lies, then it's unethical; and there are ways to word "thing"s to avoid lying.

        Actors pretend to be other people all the time; but they do not usually lie about their identity (although stage names are wonderful...).

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        W6
        Post:
        RE: W6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        14 April 2017 03:03
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        Topic #1

        Discrimination's unethical, and shouldn't be financially supported by those who're being discriminated against.

        Topic #2

        It's more like a mozzie/ant/bee biting a human; where a swarm of bees'll've a drastic impact, "I" alone willn't. If "I"'mn't co-operating with other busy bees, then "I" need not concern myself with the hive.

        If they redistributed all of their wealth, then "I"'d be able to afford to live life without piracy.

        Topic #3

        You appear to be taking a neutral stance here; so I'll attempt a deconstruction instead...

        There probably is a logical reason for their doing what they do, or it might just be incompetence / bureaucracy.

        Your first sentence seems like you're 50/50.

        I am not aware of the exact debate on release dates for the Australian market,

        I think this is irrelevant; but I would say the release dates depend on the product/organisation/logistics.

        but it seems quite strange that they can't somehow manage to release US content in Australia at more or less the exact same time

        This seems to be a conspiracy theory; leaning towards the side of piracy.

        since they do not even have to translate / dub the content.

        This evidence supports piracy.

        Judging by the way you worded it, I'd say you're reluctantly supportive of piracy due to release dates.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        Thread:
        W1 - TL1
        Post:
        RE: W1 - TL1
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        14 April 2017 01:19
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        My first two claims of a straw-man argument are valid; but my third should have been non-sequitur, as you seem to misunderstand my side of this argument. My examples only follow your own, whether you acknowledge it, or not; they are no different from your clumsy war example. Your attempting to turn wine (unethical) into water (ethical). Your argument of "some might argue that [...]" is just personal morality, which is an oxymoron; people will argue justification for what they want, not what they think is ethical.

        Utilitarianism is consequentialism, and it does not support war; clearly you did not even read the Wikipedia article: "Utilitarianism is an ethical theory that states that the best action is the one that maximizes utility. "Utility" is defined in various ways, usually in terms of the well-being of sentient entities, such as human beings and other animals."; your barbaric argument is unsupported by utilitarianism, because war is universally unethical. Since when should any group of people decide their dispute should forcibly include the rest of their nation just because they made such pathetic diplomatic attempts as a child would? I only disagree with your argument because it is wrong (link). Consequentialism doesn't argue that every cause can produce ethical consequences; there are causes which will always produce unethical consequences. Your argument is that war can somehow be justified ethically, and I disagree with it; as it is a straw-man argument.

        Re cutting in lines, read this: https://www.quora.com/Why-do-people-in-China-always-cut-in-line-Is-it-because-Im-a-foreigner
        Your argument is mundane.

        Re Gandhi the racist...
        Some dispute it: https://thewire.in/73522/gandhi-and-africans/
        Some support it: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-34265882
        For all we know, Ashwin Desai, and Goolam Vahed, were probably of those in league with the assassin responsible for the demise of Gandhi; but regardless, someone raised by racists will support racism by association, until they are enlightened. Wikipedia says "Bhana and Vahed argue that Gandhi, at first, shared racial notions prevalent of the times and that his experiences in jail sensitised him to the plight of South Africa's indigenous peoples."

        Re rape versus war...
        War is a personal "-thing"; why else do people decide to sacrifice human lives to settle a failed diplomatic dispute?
        Rape has long-term psychological, and physical, consequences for the victim; and even for the assailant, as they are likely to become a repeat offender.
        Rape is less unethical than war because nobody dies, and it impacts fewer people; in both the short-term, and the long-term.
        Your argument is mundane.

        Re slavery...
        Just because someone wants to do something, and even attempts to morally justify it, does not make it ethical; this is comparable to insanity.
        Just because someone believes they are doing the right thing, does not make it ethical; cultural relativism is no different to personal morality, which is a bandwagon argument of an oxymoron.
        This is like mistreating your brother in an attempt to treat them; another oxymoron, and is only due to negligence.
        Slavery is not ethical.
        Your argument is mundane.

        Re bandwagoning...
        Ethics is comparable to science/mathematics/ETC; there are a lot of theories, but theory ≠ fact.
        Some may choose to believe that life, the universe, and everything, revolves around the Earth; but scientists know the Earth orbits the sun.
        There is a difference between a belief that something is ethical, and it factually being ethical.

        Utilitarianism does not support your argument that war can be ethical; utilitarianism is not blindly concerned with consequences producing happyness, but with the "well-being of sentient entities".

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        If you allow them to save face, they may become a repeat offender; by being "not nice", they will learn their lesson, and be more considerate in the future; overall, this would improve the relationship in the long-run, and is thus a worthy/ethical investment.

        Thread:
        Week 5 Tutorial
        Post:
        RE: Week 5 Tutorial
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        13 April 2017 01:52
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        2.
        I agree that censorship is bad, but I think it's necessary to enforce certain laws. I would like it to be open-sourced (freedom of information), along with the reasons for censorship; but that approach is burdened with providing a list of addresses to illicit content, for which criminals would surely make use of.

        Advantages:
         * Censorship of child pornography.
         * Censorship of hate/terrorist sites.
         * Censorship of instructions for unlawful activities, making explosives, ETC.
         * Censorship of shock sites.
         * Censorship of trolling/bullying.
         * Censorship of memes/emoticons/ETC.

        3.
        Performing background checks without informed consent is a violation of research ethics concerning human subject research.

        4.
        I sure wouldn't want to employ someone who deliberately damages their braincells on a regular basis; it's counter productive to their professional development, and competence. #ACS

        5,6.
        I think ghost bloggers/tweeters/writers/ETC exist because the ghost wants to reach a wider audience, usually without compromising the image of the personality they use as an alter ego.

        : Claiming to be the author when you aren't the author, is a lie.
        : Lying is unethical.
        ∴ Hiring ghosts is unethical.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴

        Thread:
        week 4 tute question 3 - lying on resume
        Post:
        RE: week 4 tute question 3 - lying on resume
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        13 April 2017 00:45
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        Sometimes the consequences of a lie can be "nice", and promote happyness; EG lying to a friend to keep their surprise birthday party a secret. If you lie to an employer by saying that you lack certain skills, or haven't worked in the industry for as long as you ℝeally have, and they decide to hire you for it regardless (EG due to a skills-shortage); they could be impressed, and even decide to promote you; as such, a lie (something unethically "not nice") could therefore be ethical.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Sorry for mistyping your name!

        Also, utilitarianism is not about happyness at the expense of others. Wikipedia says "Utilitarianism is an ethical theory that states that the best action is the one that maximizes utility. "Utility" is defined in various ways, usually in terms of the well-being of sentient entities, such as human beings and other animals."; no support for war there.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        W1 - TL1
        Post:
        RE: W1 - TL1
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        12 April 2017 23:41
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leanard,

        Choosing the lesser of two evils does not make either of the evils ethical; scope/context have no bearing on ethicality. Doing anything without knowledge of the consequences is unethical; "I forgot to ask if they had any allergies, but it wasn't unethical of me to feed them even though I effectively poisoned them to death, because they were starving, and beggars can't be choosers". With your maniacal mind you could justify anything; "killing all the Jews will be a step towards world peace due to a reduction in diversity, and therefore killing all of the Jews is ethical is some wacky way because it will facilitate world peace". War by itself is unethical. War to defend your country from invaders is also unethical, as there are always alternative solutions to every problem (in this case it's diplomacy). War is no different to stealing to feed your family; begging, although unethical, is more ethical than stealing. Your argument is that something "not nice" can be ethical, which is not a valid argument; as the ends do not justify the means. Pulling a trigger, pushing a button, driving, ETC; by themselves have neutral ethicality. I view ethicality on the mathematical number line, with unethical as negative values, and ethical as positive values; where driving, pushing buttons, and pulling triggers, are zero (in between negative/positive). Ethicality is not zero dimensional.

        You specifically said WWIII, which will involve nuclear warfare given the sheer quantity of nuclear weapons distributed across the planet; therefore, your argument is a straw-man argument. But any war will not make people happy, just by the consequences, because they'd be happy without the war in the first place; much more happy than if there was a war. People will die during a war, and that is a fact you cannot avoid. This is like attempting to justify rape, because the victim will be happier after it is over, than during the raping. Just because some (link) Chinese are rude, does not mean you racially stereotype an entire culture!!! This is, yet again, another straw-man argument.

        Your statement about me prioritising an appointment over being there for a relative (definitely not you, thank God!) is not based on anything I have typed; thus another straw-man argument. As I said with cutting in line due to an emergency, it is a choice between two evils; with the lesser evil being the priority.

        I stand corrected about concentration camps, but I tend to think of POW camps as fundamentally different; due to the propaganda of Nazi concentration camps, concentration camps have become synonymous for me.

        I feel the same way about your argument; but you do not understand mine at all. Mine is that you cannot justify unethical actions by the consequences of the action. Utilitarianism is about happyness. Your argument is that "not nice" can produce happyness, and can therefore be ethical. But with your use of "not nice" producing happyness, you could justify slavery as ethical (for which you can be the first just to prove your point).

        The consequences do not justify the cause. The justification of war being ethical has nothing to do with utilitarianism, as war is all about suffering, and utilitarianism is all about happyness; you are just trying to fall on a mirage, because your argument is an oxymoron. Even if it's against an oppressor, there is an ethical alternative to war/terrorism/ETC; Gandhi proves an example.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None

        W6 Tute Q1 - Photos of graffiti
        Post:
        RE: W6 Tute Q1 - Photos of graffiti
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        12 April 2017 21:59
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Timothy,

        Just because there is no fence around private property, does not mean it isn't trespassing if I ride my skateboard down their "publicly accessible" stair-set. Information is intellectual property; it doesn't need to be locked up to be private. Someone could make a website without securing it so they can access it from wherever they are at the time; but not give permission to anyone else to access it. Most websites are hosted on privately-owned servers.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        Ethical Hacking
        Post:
        RE: Ethical Hacking
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        12 April 2017 21:03
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Huon,

        That's like consuming food without reading the ingredients, then having an allergic reaction, and claiming a lack of knowledge. Even if the software is "closed-source", you can still decompile/disassemble it; most software does "-thing"s without your knowledge. There are also auto-updaters, with which a rogue employee could abuse with malicious intent; EG they literally gain access to the command-line. Evidence can be falsified, and users can be framed.

        It's a double standard to say it's ethical to share something with one person, and not the public. And I think they should have computer licenses, like driving licenses; a license to use computers, where the user is made aware of the risks, and stuff.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        W1 - TL1
        Post:
        RE: W1 - TL1
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        12 April 2017 00:25
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        The motivation behind unethical behaviour is irrelevant to the behaviour itself; that is just an attempted justification of unethical behaviour, and such motivation is probably as unethical as the behaviour itself.

        I'm using pure logic here; if killing is not unethical, then it must be ethical. Killing can only be one, or the other; you cannot create exceptions just because you feel like it. Mistreating other people is unethical; even if you do it with "nice" intentions, it doesn't make it ethical. If there is something wrong with your brother, you should consult a professional who actually possesses relevant knowledge/skills to remedy his situation; rather than doing whatever the hell you feel like doing, just because you think it's going to work, and then weakly attempting to justify your actions. It is irresponsible to make uneducated assumptions; it's like not reading the manual, nor privacy policies, ETC. When you purchase software, the license provides legal obligations; and when you purchase any other type of product, there may be some similar agreement. EG Ticketek has a Resale of tickets & scalping (link) policy. Reselling is fine, if it is performed by a registered business; as is the denial of service by the original seller. You could make the exact same argument by saying you can rent out your house, so why not rent out video games? (From the tutorial sheet...) And again, I'll make use of pure logic; if bullying is not unethical, then it must be ethical. Buying everything is selfish, and selfish is unethical; just imagine a rich billionaire buys all the food from your area, and you starve to death because of it. If you haven't read the prescribed textbook; bullying can be lethal. Ethics is not intangible. It's purely logical/mathematical; a+b=c, where a is negative, and b is positive; whatever c is, a will always remain negative, and b will always remain positive. Perspective has nothing to do with it; ethics is not about improving your own situation; the attempted justification of unethical acts just because it benefits yourself does not make it ethical. Firefighters have sirens on their vehicles, along with standardised protocols supported by driving license tests, to facilitate driving above the speed limit without putting others at risk. If your house burns down, that's fine by me; but if you are responsible for damaging other peoples property, and even the deaths of other people, that is not. Firefighters are not trespassing, because the Queen/Country owns the land. There is a nuance, you are just too blind to consider it; your perspective is ignorantly fawlty. You should proved evidence for line cutting in other countries (wiki). Leaving the line to use the bathroom, and then returning to your original position, is not necessarily cutting in line. Cutting in line for an emergency is not ethical, it is just the best of two evils. Stealing a cookie bears no relevance to saving the world; this is a non-sequitur argument. Fall-out radiation is not irrelevant to WWIII; and you are producing a straw-man argument, by being inconsiderate of the "nuclear" aspect of WWIII; or being ignorant towards any other such aspect for that matter. WWIII will not necessarily involve concentration camps, as that is a unique feature of the Nazi involvement with WWII. You have failed to provide a valid argument where "not nice" is not unethical; the consequences of an unethical act have no bearing on the ethicality of the act itself.

        I would hate to be related to you, or even friends with you; for if I die, I want to be remembered by those closest to me, as it means I have had an impact on their lives. But, by the sounds of it, your life is pretty dull/repetitive anyway...

        Bad is not a prerequisite for good.
        War is not a prerequisite for peace.
        Homework is a non-sequitor argument, as it is a measure of skill.

        Your dogma is significantly fawlty, and your critical reasoning is illogical; I feel like I'm communicating with Eric Cartman...

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        To stage the terrorist attack, they could drive around in a vehicle full of firearms/explosives; without the intention to actually put them to use.

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        Appeal to popularity is a fallacy; you could all think life, the universe, and everything, revolves around this planet for all I care.

        The case study does not state the legality of the website. This is no different to accessing copyrighted material uploaded to YouTube/Imgur/ETC; these are legitimate websites, which can be used for piracy; but just because copyrighted material is hosted by them, does not mean it is illegal/unethical to access the copyrighted material. Your iTunes example is irrelevant.

        Thread:
        W5 Tute Q2 - Internet censorship
        Post:
        RE: W5 Tute Q2 - Internet censorship
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        11 April 2017 21:54
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        : Website A is legal in Country A.
        : Website A is illegal in Country B.
        : Person B cannot legally access Website A from within their own country.
        : Person B can legally visit Country A.
        ∴ Person B can legally visit Website A.
        … This is like sex tourism...

        ...

        The problem is when hate groups act on their hate speech, and turn words into violence.

        Hate groups can spread like a viral infection; due to falsified claims (link), and contagious psychological manipulation (hate by association, illogical/uncritical reasoning, ETC). Agora™ (link) is a movie that comes to mind; the Christian walks through the middle of an entire epic fire pit unscathed due to the density of his clothing, and then pushes a thinly clothed ¿Jew? over the edge, and into the flaming pit, whom then lights up like a sparkler (it's a common theme throughout the film, Christians bullying Jews (sticks, and stones, may break my bones...), but the plot is more focused on paganism; the end is scientifically spiritual, and/or spiritually scientific...). I was surprised to find out the Vatican supported Agora™, but apparently it's littered with historical inaccuracies (link).

        Left unchecked, hate groups can turn into what ISIS has become, and what the president of the Usa wants his nation to become; especially when the leader of your country is doing it, as the leader serves as a representation of the national majority (link). This reminds me of the tutorial question regarding unethical behaviour by senior managers, compared with that of...cannon fodder?

        Therefore, I support the consideration of hate speech as a heinous crime. Ethics is to the ℝeal world, as mathematics is to the ℝeal world; there are ℝealistic exceptions.

        ...

        : Countries are obligated to protect their citizens.
        : If Country B death sentences a citizen of Country A,
        ∴ Country A should retaliate by threatening to kill citizens of Country B.
        … I feel like countries could do more to protect their citizens from other countries; the country is extorting tax, so it's like a gangster-based protection/insurance scam...

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        Ethical Hacking
        Post:
        RE: Ethical Hacking
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        11 April 2017 20:27
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Huon,

        I mean public release.

        Most, if not all, malware is released without any licensing whatsoever.

        By explicitly authorising users to redistribute your malware, they would not be infringing on your rights when they "accidentally" distribute your malware to other users; otherwise it's extra malicious because they'd also be conducting unethical behaviour by redistributing your malware.

        I believe malware, as intellectual property, is no different to any other software; and as such, is therefore subject to intellectual property laws.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        Tute W5, W6 quick answers.
        Post:
        RE: Tute W5, W6 quick answers.
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        11 April 2017 19:41
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Darren,

        W5 Q5: You skipped this question!

        W6 Q1: If a person is in public space, can they be photographed? As long as you reference they personal details? Without their consent?

        W6 Q2: The only ownership the case study provides, is that of the cousin.

        W6 Q3: You also need authorisation from the proprietor for renting.

        W6 Q4: The music/tune is also copyrighted (not only the lyrics).

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴

        Week 6 TL Q's
        Post:
        RE: Week 6 TL Q's
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        09 April 2017 15:19
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello World,

        1.
        Humans don't usually guide the growth of plants; but buildings are forms of street art, and should be treated as such. Graffiti is usually claimed by a tag, just as images are watermarked.

        2.
        It depends on the original licensing/agreement between you, and your cousin; you may be the author, but they may be the owner since you wrote it specifically for their business.

        4.
        What about fan-made content; not a mash-up per se, but fan-fiction can conflict with what the author/owner has in mind for canon/continuity.

        How do you measure how much music belongs to whom? If the mash-up contains no original music, as it could just be remixing two songs into one; who ℝeally owns it?

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Week 5 TL Qs
        Post:
        RE: Week 5 TL Qs
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        09 April 2017 14:48
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello World,

        3,4.
        The Internet is not a public space, because servers are privately owned. The robots exclusion protocol is no different than putting up a "private property" sign in front of your house. Is it okay for me to trespass on your lawn, granted there are no anti-trespassing signs, even though it isn't public property? I may want to enjoy resting on your luscious green grass, and pick some of your fragrant flowers; I could also peek in through your windows/doors (and jump through if they're open/unlocked), and stuff... Search engines provide the illusion of public space; but just because you can access, doesn't mean you should.

        Research ethics are relevant when conducting any form of human subject research. Without informed consent, we should not use other peoples property; not even to just cut across the lawn to save time, because it's more convenient. If the collected information is owned by the (social media) website, due to T&Cs, then it should not be used to judge the human subject.

        5.
        There are many websites which hire people to write on their behalf, without attribution; it's like using image/sound file without attribution. A blog is essentially a business, generated from adware revenue.

        6.
        This reminds me of Thomas Edison...

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        Is the ACS Code of Conduct and Ethics a sham?
        Post:
        RE: Is the ACS Code of Conduct and Ethics a sham?
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        08 April 2017 00:14
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Matthew,

        If I ever become an ACS patron, I will be under strict obligation to disclose this information about you.

        I have been a member of the ACS in the past and received the introduction pack including the Code of Conduct and Code of Ethics.

        Why are you no longer a patron?

        I, like many people, did not read them.

        Your anecdotal argument does not provide any evidence of anyone else not reading into the ACS propaganda, specifically.

        I had no need to read them as I am ethical and follow my own code of conduct which is developed from the social circles that I interact with and my family values.

        Personal morality is an oxymoron ∵ it would be immoral not to consider other personal moralities. And your opinion has no ethical/legal weight; in fact, as an ACS patron, it is unethical for you to not have read the ACS propaganda! (This proves your personal morality is an oxymoron ■)

        I believe that many ACS members have not read the Codes.

        Your personal beliefs are irrelevant ∵ valid arguments should be atheistic in nature.

        In assignment 1, I researched how often people would read the privacy policies on websites and found that 80% of people did not read privacy policies and those who did, did not understand them.

        This is a red herring by the texas sharpshooter ∵ privacy policies of websites are irrelevant to an argument concerning ACS propaganda.

        I would argue that the same is occurring with the ACS Code of Conduct and Ethics.

        Your bandwagon argument is based on irrelevance; there is no statistical correlation ∵ website privacy policies are almost as abundant as websites themselves, and ACS propaganda is as exiguous as the quantity of organisations like ACS ∴ it is more likely the ACS propaganda will be read; but you use self-referential evidence that there is/were a percentage of unethical ACS patrons (although, since you are no longer a patron; it leads to the conclusion that such patronage is rather short-lived).

        ...

        Even if every ACS member did read the codes, there is no assurance mechanism such as the police to monitor the adherence to the codes.

        This is false ∵ the ACS propaganda incorporates self-governance in 1.2.6.b (link) of Professionalism in the ACS Code of Professional Conduct, and 6 (link) of the ACS Code of Ethics is autonomous.

        For example, if an ACS member was to get fired for unethical behaviour or conduct (i.e. the most common reason people get fired) then there is no way the ACS would find out.

        This is false. I have contributed evidence to this forum (at least in thread "Tute statement no.6"), regarding the food industry; which it is entirely conceivable of occurring in other industries. A correlation can also be derived from a criminal record, and the temporal statistics of dismissal.

        Additionally, it is illegal for a company to tell others why an employee was fired and it is detrimental to the ex-employees career to tell the ACS.

        Can you provide evidence that "it is illegal for a company to tell others why an employee was fired"?
        Disclosure is not detrimental to their career, only to their relationship with ACS; and why is it ex-employee?

        ...

        So I ask you, are the ACS Code of Conduct and Ethics a sham?

        Not by your argument.

        If 80% of members don't read the codes, is the ACS a more ethical organisation by simply having a code?

        This is unsupported by your argument.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        🖖 Hello Victor,

        I've never been able to tell the difference between public property, and private property...
        If there are no private property signs, is it ℝeally illegal?
        If there are no anti-trespassing signs, is it legal to trespass?
        If there are no anti-arting signs, is it         legal to art?
        If there are no anti-skateboarding signs, is it         legal to skateboard? (Because skateboarding is a form of art. LOL ROFL XD)

        Just because it is illegal, doesn't mean it should not be respected; EG it may be illegal to write about certain subjects (EG Galileo Galilei, the heretic). It's a double standard to only respect it if it's done well; my scribbles on the wall deserve to be worshiped by society!

        Illegal graffiti can have political agendas, be used to spread awareness, ETC; EG it's like throwing cans of red paint at people who parade around in the skins of violated animals (which is effectively graffiti on private property/individuals (is it legal to graffiti the popo?), even if it takes place on public property; like bombing a vehicle...a popo vehicle; now that earns you street cred/rep/ETC!).

        We can always just graffiti/deface the anti-everything signs, and then it will be like they never even existed in the first place...

        🖖 Hello Mark,

        Social media information isn't public; it's stored on servers which are not public, and the information is intended to be shared within social circles (unlike a blog?). Treating it as public information is like overhearing someone gossip about their life to a friend; you could just be walking by, or you could be stalking (performing human subject research).

        I imagine parsing through social media is like using a visual microphone (link).

        🖖 Hello Mark,

        You could provide the software for free, but sell the documentation for how to use it. You could also charge for tech support; some people do not know how to install software, and will even pay techies to do it on their behalf. You could also charge for training their employees to use it. You could also charge for security/bug patches, feature requests, ETC. I'm sure there are even more creative/lucrative ways to scam people for their valuables...

        Selling software is like selling mathematical equations; "oh, you have a pet venus fly trap, and you want to by another one, but you need to know how many you will have in total? 1+1=2, and that will will be 3 slips of gold-pressed latinum".

        This is a common automated tacit programming tool for Haskell: http://pointfree.io/

        I can guarantee that you will never be able to identify the programmer if they use that tool (I don't know of any Haskellers who do not use that tool; there is also a console-based version for convenience sake).

        Computer programs can be treated mathematically (especially declarative paradigms, with their disorderly processing of operations); which is why compiler/assembler/ETC optimisations are even possible in the first place (at least until we solve natural language processing; which would make programming languages obsolete anyway).

        There are many reasons for poverty; but it's got a lot to do with poor people wanting to enjoy life in the now, by wasting their money on "-thing"s they don't ℝeally need (alcohol/caffeine/drugs/tobacco/gambling/ETC), which will not improve their situation, nor quality of life; rather than working towards a better future.

        I am poor, but not starving (link), without begging, nor stealing; and I am working towards improving my own livelihood, which is why I am here. I plan to be fit (sic erat scriptum), and wealthy.

        Japan made it illegal to be fat, and I think the rest of the world should follow their example; the world would be sleightly less humongorous, but it would disable an entire disability.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        W5 Tute Q1 - Ethical and Anonymous
        Post:
        RE: W5 Tute Q1 - Ethical and Anonymous
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        06 April 2017 11:15
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Timothy,

        Elastic tabstops         (link) will unite all of the coders; therefore, tabs vs spaces will be a "-thing" of the past...

        Source-to-source compilers can remove bias, and allow anyone to write code for any project.

        There are also tools to manipulate the source code; indentation, namespaces (including camelCase/snake_case conversion without changing the actual name), conditional statements, multi/mono line, ETC.

        Coding conventions are used to remove bias; but I am a programmer who likes to automate the task of complying with coding conventions via PCRE, ETC, because I do my best not to perform any malpractice devised by some PHB (wiki).

        Ninja vs Pirate, (COMPLETE); Ninja wins this round!

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        W6
        Post:
        RE: W6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath

        Post:
        RE: W5 Tute Q3 - assess job candidate on social media
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        05 April 2017 22:24
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Joseph,

        GitHub provides private repositories (for a fee), otherwise all the software/data is publicly available; GitHub legal buffs maintain that "Unless you include a license that specifies otherwise, nobody else can use, copy, distribute, or modify your work without being at risk of take-downs, shake-downs, or litigation.", even for public repositories.

        Your Grav-Mass example is irrelevant to matters concerning intellectual property.

        If I can ever prove that someone performed human subject research on me, without my informed consent, I will take them to court over it; guilty as charged!

        I need start a viral PSA campaign to spread awareness...

        Links:
         * GitHub maintains choosealicense.com
         * Grav-Mass
         * The Privacy Act says what you are doing is illegal

        🖖 Hello Huon,

        A program as just a list of instructions for a "-thing" to follow; whether it's mechanical, biological, or somewhere in between, a program is just a list of instructions to me. The deli could have different products (what is inventory?) during different times of the day, or different days of the week; like a television program, there could be subliminal messaging in the order of how everything plays out. In some media skills class, i learnt of a painter who painted canvases one color each and his gallery was just different colors organised in a type of chaos, from chaos comes order. But they were arranged so that, if the viewer followed them in a direction, they would manipulate the viewers emotion. [...] There are accounts of people bursting into tears for no apparent reason. [...] (From a ~500-word something I wrote about art and psychology; basically, people can be "programmed", in more than one sense of the word.)

        Open-source software can be monetised in other ways (wiki).

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        W6
        Post:
        W6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        04 April 2017 13:15
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello World,

        Tutorial Sheet

        1.
        The licensing of graffiti photos should depend on the licensing of the graffiti itself. Making art of art, is no different than making software of software.
        2.
        2.1-
        It depends; there is no indication of ownership in the case study.
        Software is a type of "program".
        If I write software for someone else to use, then I own it.
        If I write software for someone else, then they own it.
        2.2-
        Only if I own it, and want payment; I may only desire recognition; which will will advertise my skills, and I can also use all of the deli shops as volunteer/employment references.
        3.
        Games and Copyright (G016v10) FINAL.pdf
        Lending or renting games
        Copyright law does not restrict people from lending items. However, owners of copyright in computer software and sound recordings have the right to control rental of these items. If money changes hands in connection with lending an item which includes computer software or a sound recording, the transaction may infringe copyright unless the copyright owner has given permission. For further information, see our information sheets Renting Items Protected by Copyright and Lending Items Protected by Copyright.
        Note that if you lend a game to someone knowing that they intend to copy it, you might both be liable for copyright infringement, since it is an infringement to authorise another person to infringe copyright. For further information, see our information sheet Infringement - Actions, Remedies, Offences and Penalties.
        4. Exam Query!!!
        4.1-
        This is no different than software; it depends on the licensing.
        4.2-
        They should have every right; they also have the right to not contribute to society in the first place.
        5.
        Cloud Computing is a form of globally distributed computing. Just because a client can connect with a server, does not mean the client has permission to access the server; where a client can be another server.

        Laboratory Sheet
        Topic # 1:
        Supposedly, there is a way to legally access GoT directly from HBO; but apparently, "We're sorry. This video is not available in your region."..?
        HBO stands for Hypocritically Bureaucratic Organisation.
        ...
        ITunes is expensively discriminatory.
        Amazon Prime is partially discriminative.
        HBOGo doesn't work either; "To access HBO GO℠, you must reside within the fifty states of the United States of America.".
        ...
        It appears as though there is a logical reason for the GoT' infamy for being the most pirated TV show; coincidental conspiracy?!?
        ...
        By the time their "global" releases become available, all of the hype has died out due to WWW-based spoilers; this discrimination is unethical!!!
        Topic # 2:
        Those big organisations employ small fish like you ∴ you are a treasonous traitor!!!
        Topic # 3:
        Organisations should be organised enough to temporally synchronise the release of their content on a global scale; organisations should oppose the arguments for piracy, instead of supporting them...

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        You have to ask whether it is worth sacrificing freedom to a single organisation (the government); which suffers from multiple personality disorders (term of office), and other such psychologically defective conditions.

        Facebook, Google, and other websites firewalled by China, make use the Tor network in an attempt to open potentially exploitable vulnerabilities; but China is making every effort to patch the vulnerabilities. The ethicality of the situation is an unethical firefight (fighting fire with fire); .

        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        31 March 2017 19:53
        Status:
        Published

        L = Living = positive.
        Z = Zero = cancelive.
        S = Suffering = negative.
        P = Power-offing = negative.
        H = Halting = negative. (Unless you believe in rebooting?)

        Negative/Positive is not completely zero-dimensional; H < S < P < Z < -P < -S < L.

        Suicide is a psychological bugware/malware.

        ...but lets be ℝeally ℝealistic:

        0. I'm boycotting NDAs; so I'm free to blow the whistle (disclosure) without any considerations/obligations/ETC.

        1. Make me ℝeally rich; like, an early retirement settlement would do the bribe.

        2. 'Depends how rich they made me.

        3. Who needs a conscience when you never have to work another day of your life? Life is short, and I'd rather spend my valuable time doing what I want; rather than doing what others grovel for me to do.

        5. I'd come out of hiding, as a ℝeally rich ethics advocate, to clear my conscience; if I had one...nah; I would just enjoy my valuable life, along with my bootylicious trophy wife, who would be blonde to my source of wealth, while we focus on improving our health, to...

        Thread:
        Morality vs Ethicality
        Post:
        RE: Morality vs Ethicality
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        29 March 2017 21:55
        Status:
        Published

        If someone else had the choice to kill a group of strangers, or an individual stranger; what is the ethicality of the situation?

        True morality is impersonal; personal morality is an oxymoron, because it is immoral not to consider others.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Morality vs Ethicality
        Post:
        Morality vs Ethicality
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        29 March 2017 20:41
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello World,

        What is ethical, and what is unethical? That is the query!

        I say it is idiocratic to label anything as being either ethical, or unethical; as we do not have complete knowledge over this ℝeality.
        ...
        A may think treating B negatively will ultimatumly pressure B to stop taking drugs.
        But if A studied the latest research in psychology; A would treat B positively, so B would enjoy As company more than the company of other drug addicts.
        ...
        It's purely mathematical:
         ◦ Negative + Negative = Negative.
         ◦ Positive + Negative = A chance to make the difference!!!

        Rather, a more practical approach, in an ever-changing sense of ℝeality; we should ask only, what is most ethical.

        Is it more ethical to kill a group, or an individual, with a train? It is obviously more ethical to kill an individual; even if you personally care more about the individual, than the group. (Would I be willing to sacrifice a relative/friend, for a group of strangers; no, but that doesn't mean I made an unethical decision ∵ those categories of queries are relevant to my personal morality, and not a query of impersonal morality.)

        Alternative decisions, outside of the query, should always be considerable.
        ...
        Is murder ethical? No.
        Is murder that makes us feel better about a situation, because we can't bear to see another suffer, ethical? No.
        Is stealing more ethical than murdering? Yes.
        Is stealing ethical? No.
        Is stealing food to feed your starving family ethical? No.
        Is begging more ethical than stealing? Yes.
        Is begging ethical? No.
        ...
        This (link) is a purely ethical solution!

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        W5
        Post:
        W5
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        29 March 2017 16:49
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello World,

        Tutorial Sheet

        1.
        I may be researching/browsing for my assignment, and I don't want to be tracked by adware, search engine bubbles, ETC.
        I could fall victim to XSS, session hijacking, and other cybersecurity vulnerabilities.

        2.
        Internet censorship is a waste of time ∵ proxy servers can be used to circumnavigate it.
        Advantage: Australian citizens will be absolved of any related crimes involving the censored content (unless they retain the material on their computer).
        Disadvantage: It is ineffective/unenforceable/ETC.

        3.
        It is unethical to assess potential job candidates based on their social media profile during the recruitment process ∵ it's like contacting the candidates' relatives, and friends, or even visiting the candidates house, and checking for dust on the shelves, how well-kept the lawn is, ETC; EG "this bedroom is an unprofessional mess; the bed isn't made, and it smells like someone had sex in here ∴ we won't employ them".

        4.
        It is unethical for Andy to upload pictures with a beer in his hand ∵ it is a form of adware.
        Very personal pictures should not be uploaded on a social networking site ∵ St IGNUcius says so (link).
        Alcohol is served at business parties, and embarrassing pictures may leak to the public; which could damage the reputation of the business.

        5.
        Ghostblogging is the practice of hiring a professional to blog on your behalf; EG to present you as a professional.
        Ghostblogging is ethical.
        It is the same as hiring a technical writer to make your CV appear more professional.
        It is the same as hiring a tailer to make you appear more professional.
        It is the same as hiring an artist to make your business logo appear more professional.
        ETC.

        6.
        I would tweet about my new business I just founded, great ape personhood, animal welfare, politics, and other changes I want to see in the world; as it would provide me with a wider audience.
        It is ethical ∵ it is consensual; as opposed to me cracking into their Twitter account, like some hippie animal rights activist.

        Laboratory Sheet

        "Jack all" is not abusive, "ASAP" is not offensive, and I have a personal life; I ceased writing feedback after my first SP due to my PL.
        When in Rome...
        🖖 Hello World,

        This is my feedback for CPT250; which had the absolute worst QoS I have ever experienced!!!

        The guy running the course was a total joke!!!
        All of the lectures were always plagued by delays, by weeks (take not of the plurality therein); either due to work commitments (what, is he teaching us for free?!? I thought this was his job?!?), or his ill daughter (why couldn't he do the chat at home?!? It's not like he'd be totally incapacitated by her; do it when she's unconscious!!!).

        Near the end of the SP, he set his email holiday message to inform us that he lost access to his email; which is unbelievable that RMIT wouldn't provide a sub!?!
        Followed by an email (I have just dug up) which provided a non-RMIT email address, to contact the guy supposedly running the course; which, I thought, was a taboo practice?!?

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Admitting (acknowledgement), and apologising (conscience), is ethical behaviour; but does not influence the ethicality of the motivation (cause) behind admission/apology (æffect).

        Tags:  None

        An ethical act, does not make an unethical act, ethical; or another way to say the samething, is that, unethical acts are inexcusable.

        Otherwise, that's like using a confessional box/service (God/psychologist...for the Atheistic religions) as an excuse to do whatever you want, because you can always confess to "make up for it"; it makes you feel better about yourself, but does not influence the morality behind what you have done (otherwise everybody may as well break all of the commandments, whenever it suits them, and then simply/confidentially confess about it to make amens [sic erat scriptum]).

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

        7.

        You have said, "Killing someone is not nice and surely unethical", and then immediately contradicted yourself by saying, "killing someone who is suffering is not necessarily unethical"; that is a double standard.

        Killing someone who is suffering is unethical!
        Even if you kill them because they ask you to, doesn't mean it's ethical; you could be the cause of the suffering.
        In The Final Frontier (wiki), Dr Leonard McCoy euthanised his own father (link), and later regretted it, due to a cure being discovered shortly thereafter.
        The Mist (wiki) had a controversial ending (link); where the guy murdered his own son (along with three strangers), before being rescued two minutes later.

        A wants to murder B: A says they just happen to "know" B is enduring enough suffering to justify being put down (so they can collect their inheritance, already!).

        ME wants to murder A: I say A is suffering due to ageing, and should therefore be put down. A denies, thereby providing ME with an argument of insanity (because insanity is the suffering of the mind, mentally!).

        If you consult a psychologist, they will advise you not to push your brother away like that, and to be more supportive; just because you think it's ethical, doesn't make it so!

        ...

        That is not what capitalism is built on; Google says capitalism is "an economic and political system in which a country's trade and industry are controlled by private owners for profit, rather than by the state".

        It is unethical to buyout/bully a business without their consent; it's like if I went and bought the footpath outside your house, put up a fence, and charged people to visit you.

        A right does not make a wrong, right (link); there is no right way of doing the wrong thing.
        Ethics is not about doing more good, than harm; it's about doing the right thing.
        Charities (link) aren't necessarily ethical (link).

        Just because there's a medical emergency, does not make it ethical to drive above the speed limit.
        Just because you donate to charity, doesn't mean you can cut in line.
        Just because you do something good, doesn't mean you can do something bad.

        8.

        You said WWIII could "could indirectly contribute to making them more happy in the end once the war is over"; this is something you did actually say.
        I said it wouldn't because of fall-out radiation; which has repercussions that will linger long after the war is over.

        You even said "it wouldn't be the war per se that would be making them happy, but the indirect consequences of it"; which my statement challenges, duefully.

        You didn't need to mention a nuclear blast; I did.
        Your words are not gospel.
        And you even agree on the probability of WWIII involving nuclear warfare.
        You are contradicting your post below; in which, you claim that "when faced with ambiguity, it is common practice to go for the most likely interpretation given the context - or address the few likely interpretations.".
        You appear to be floundering at this point...
        It doesn't matter how low your standards of happyness are, the aftereffects of WWIII will not make anyone happy; you are delusional!
        People lose relatives, and friends, without a WW; and are not happy, consequently.
        I don't think you even understand what a WW is!?!

        Your existence is irrelevant.
        For some twisted reason, you seem to think good can come from WW; when you mentioned WWIII as an "extreme example", I rightfully refuted it.

        You need to actually think about what you type.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        Thread:
        invalid, sound arguments
        Post:
        RE: invalid, sound arguments
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        28 March 2017 12:22
        Status:
        Published

        I would say that if an argument is sound, by itself (without mentioning validity); then it must be valid.

         
        But if you say an argument is invalid, and sound/unsound; then it's clear the conclusion isn't drawn from the premises, and the premises are true/false;.
        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        invalid, sound arguments
        Post:
        RE: invalid, sound arguments
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        28 March 2017 12:06
        Status:
        Published

        The 12ᵗʰ lecture slide says validity is determined by assuming the premises are true, and drawing the conclusion from them.

         
        The 3ʳᵈ step, of the  7-step strategy for for evaluating arguments, just questions validity; the 5 ᵗʰ step then says to check the validity again, which would mean no argument can be inductive. Which is illogical, so my 5ᵗʰ step is basically just the 4ᵗʰ step; but sound=inductive, and unsound=fallacious.
        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        invalid, sound arguments
        Post:
        RE: invalid, sound arguments
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        28 March 2017 11:49
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

         
        My understanding, from the W3 Tutorial sheet, is that soundness is just an indication of the truthfulness of the premises.
        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

        Posted Date:
        28 March 2017 00:00
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Eugene,

         
         
        Personal morality is an oxymoron because it is akin to sanity; personal morality holds back pure morality.
        Sexists/racists/ETC are deliberately inconsiderate of others, because it suits them.
        It is immoral to sacrifice human life; why not contribute to society instead, by putting them to use? ( EG substitutes for animal testing, whilst providing animals with personhood/rights! )
        It is immoral to sacrifice animal life; why else do they use terms such as butchering/slaughtering/ETC? ( Even the Spartans weren't as mentally twisted as that; they ethically ensured their human sacrifices were as swift as possible, from the highest drop they could find. )
        Euthanasia, and the capital punishment, are conflicts of interest; cannot logically/sanely support both.
        Domesticated pets, and animal consumption, are conflicts of interest; cannot logically/sanely support both.
        There is no humane way to take a life; unless you want to try it out for yourself, just to prove a point? ( I'll even eat you afterwards, if you want; I'm okay with it, as long as it's mutually consensual, without the use of mind altering substances, nor hypnosis, nor blackmail, nor psychological influences, ETC. )
        Just because it's legal/accepted, doesn't mean it's ethical/rational; EG many countries support domestic violence, ( rape ) victim blaming, ETC.
         
         
        Morality can be a public matter.
        I call myself a hacker ( without malicious intent ), meanwhile others give hacking a bad name by donning a black pirate hat whilst they hack; t his is akin to samurai who break Bushido being hunted by other samurai, in an effort to clear the name of all true samurai .
        People used to be considered representative of their nation, and could be punished for embarrassing the nation ( but now the nation is afraid to lose its' heads ); also treason ( ¡vive la révolution! ), and such.
         
         
        Clothing is...l ike, why does everybody wear such retardedly studid looking clothing? ( And yes, I do mean all of you reading this. )
        Different time periods is like looking at the tree rings of society; it's always totally insane what people will wear, just because everyone else is...being socially engineered?
        From corsets, to suits; people are willing to endure discomfort, to the point of " getting used to it ".
        Clothing conventions are just as unethical as coding conventions; I do not follow coding conventions, because I just use a text formatter / regular expressions, so I can code how I want!
        To hell with the industry, suffering from its' self-inflicted skills-shortage, the Google Raid ( link ), and my self-empowerment; if I want to wear a sombrero to the interview, and also be considered " professional " ( because ℝeal programmers wear hats; which is an industry standard, and the reason why the Google propellerheads' wear helicopter hats ), then I'll just sit on the dole until a ℝeal employment opportunity comes my way.
        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        Thread:
        Implicit biases and assumptions in premises
        Post:
        RE: Implicit biases and assumptions in premises
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        27 March 2017 16:20
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

         
        The second premise says we have come into possession of the Chip X design specification.
        The first premise says we visited the campus where it's being field tested, and is likely where we came into possession of the Chip X design specification.
        The third premise says our colleague participated in the field testing of Chip X at the campus we visited ( which could overlap with our visitation during the first premise; increasingly probable, due to corroboration ); and it's likely we came into possession of the Chip X design specification from our colleague.
         
        The conclusion can use the possession of the Chip X design specification as an indication of its' point of origin.
        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        My answers to W3 Tute Sheet
        Post:
        RE: My answers to W3 Tute Sheet
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        27 March 2017 12:37
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Craig,

         
        1.
         
        (e) The invalidity of the argument is agreeable; but the argument is also unsound ∵ some piano players may watch footy matches IℝL .
         
        2. I disagree with these:
         
        Oh come on, I've been feeling sick. That's why I failed the exam
         - red herring ∵ a doctor would've delayed the exam ∴ ill's unexcusable.
         
        I don't care what you say. We don't need any more bookshelves. As long as the carpet is clean, we are fine
         - non sequitur ∵ the interdependent relationship between the carpet, and the bookshelves, is illogical.
         
        I know I forgot to deposit the check into the bank yesterday. But, nothing I do pleases you
         - appeal to pity ∵ it is an attempt to induce guilt in order to misdirect attention away from forgetfulness.
         
        The government doesn't take care of the poor because it doesn't have a tax specifically to support the poor
         - straw man argument  ∵ just because there isn't a poverty tax, doesn't mean tax is not used to support the poor ∴ the lack of a poverty tax, is  a weaker representation of the truth.
         
        3.
         
        Surveys are a formal means of data collection, whereby the organisation conducting the survey must be represented in a professional manner, because the survey will contribute to the reputation of the organisation; nobody wants to do business with, nor invest their livelihood in, an organisation run by amateurish delinquents ( EG It would be unethical to ask for passwords, credit card numbers, ETC ).

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        W1 - TL1

        🖖 Hello Leonard,

         
        7.
        The case study does not provide any information regarding the legal status of the website. The copyrighted films could be provided for free via adware/donations; for which, royalties could be paid to the IP owners.  Humble Bundle ( link ) provides copyright material at " Pay What You Want! ", which can be effectively free. In another thread, it was mentioned; " [...] Chance the Rapper, an unsigned artist, published his new album on SoundCloud for free ([...]) after releasing it first on Apple Music. [...] " --  Tom Carlton .
         
        9.
        Crowdfunding, adware, or/and ETC; provides content creators with resources, support, and/or ETC.

        Thread:
        Week Tutorial Questions and Lab Task
        Post:
        RE: Week Tutorial Questions and Lab Task
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        27 March 2017 09:01
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Eugene,

        I guess I should explain the karmic reaction reference...

        If one person does something, it is highly probably others will/are also doing it.
        So if you do it, then it means others are/will also do it.
        The probability of it being done to you, increases the more you do it; as it means others are likely doing it more/less than you.
        Higher populations also increase the probability.

        🖖 Hello Petrus,

        What constitutes sufficiently secured/protected?

        If you put a lock on your door, is it enough to keep me out of your house?
        You can always do more; bar the windows, make floors/walls/ceiling diamond (impenetrable), ETC.
        But I'll always find a weakness; which is usually found sitting between keyboard, and chair.

        I think non-intrusive blockchains are better, because they do away with traditional DRM.

        Thread:
        W4: 7ᵗʰ chat slide
        Post:
        W4: 7ᵗʰ chat slide
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        25 March 2017 09:35
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello World,

        So, I'm reading the chat slides for week 4; and I'm up to the 7ᵗʰ slide...

        There is a skills shortage in the industry, and the Google Raid (link) is outsourcing jobs to Australia; this slide is so retarded, that I'm surprised it hasn't yet gone the way of the dodo!?!
        I do not see how, nor why, this is a matter of ethics; to pay more for outsource, than to pay less for insource.
        It's like paying more for local services, than paying less at the superevil supermarkets.
        South Park explored this; in the end, the local shops became the big giant evil corporations.
        Why would it be ethical for me to spend more money, when there are cheaper alternatives?!?
        It is unethical for local shops to charge as much as they do.
        It is unethical for local employees to charge as much as they do.
        It's very easy to flip the table on these; therefore, I consider these matters outside the scope of ethics.
        People need to make a living, but why should I support them? It's not like they are reciprocating; why should I get ripped off by the corner store, just because it's sleightly closer than the supermarket?

        Actually, I've changed my mind; it is unethical to overcharge; for products, services, ETC; by customers, employees, employers, ETC.
        But we live in a competitive ℝeality, where everyone is trying to rip each other off; it's just business.
        The most ethical model I can think of, is a health-based economy; where resources are allocated depending on an individuals' mental, and physical, health.
        This would improve our development/evolution, as a species (AKA the Quality of Life); but it doesn't take decrepit/defective units into consideration (Earth=Sparta), and is probably for the best (invalids are invalid forms of life, undeserving of personhood; and humanitarians are hippies).
        Most businesses are irrelevant anyway; people will do whatever they can to make money, and others will fall for it.
        The affluent president of the Usa acts, and looks, like a gullible retard; when others do business with him, they foolishly think they are the hustlers (he is still surviving in the industry for a reason, and just gives the impression that he's the idiot; but he knows the industry better than you).
        Social Engineering is the reason why the Usa accent sounds dumber than an Eu accent.

        Idiocracy is my favourite movie, because I feel like I'm living in it; woe is me!

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        🖖 Hello Joseph,

        Does that make it impossible for Australian citizens to be accused of piracy?
        Is that virtually legalised piracy? (Without saying so much so.)

        Let person A be in country A.
        Let it be illegal to download movie X in country A, for free.
        Is it illegal for person A to download movie X from a country B, for free?
        What if it is legal in the country B?

        I got an illegal video game mailed over from overseas, off Ebay/Amazon; I still have it...

        This is how you land (link) the job:

        🖖 Hello World,

        I have referable, and demonstrable, experience with throwing grapes into my mouth.

        I can throw grapes into my mouth at any time of the day, or the night; and at any time in between day, and night.

        I can throw grapes ℝeally high, and still catch them in my mouth; but my skills are not limited, because I can also drop grapes into my mouth.

        I can even catch grapes thrown by a 3rd party; unless there are circular dependencies...

        I can throw, and catch, multiple grapes at once.

        And just for you; I will spit the grape out of my mouth, and catch it again! I own the rights for this one, so there's no contest. ;-)

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        Don't sell yourself short; but there's a ℝeally fine line between lying, and exaggerating.

        The exaggeration: I precisely threw the grape up ℝeally high into the air; it got some serious hang-time, before it's pre-calculated trajectory ensured its' landing in my open mouth. There was some minor aerodynamic turbulence on the way down, as to be expected; but I solved that minor technical difficulty, by adjusting the Angle/vector/Position of my head, to compensate for the ever-so-sleight change in trajectory.

        The lie: I THREW THE GRAPE, AND IT BOUNCED OF YOUR HEAD, LANDED ON THE CEILING FAN, THEN GOT FLUNG OFF, BOUNCED OFF THE CEILING, BOUNCED OFF THE WALL, BOUNCED OFF THE CEILING AGAIN, BEFORE CATCHING IT PERFECTLY BETWEEN MY TEETH, WHILST I WAS IN THE MIDDLE OF A FRONT FLIP; IT WAS LIKE A NINJA BULLET-CATCH!!!

        The somebody-else-will-get-the-job-even-though-you-threw-yours-sleightly-higher-than-they-did: I threw the grape into my mouth.

        Thread:
        is this argument invalid?
        Post:
        RE: is this argument invalid?
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        24 March 2017 15:22
        Status:
        Published

        P2: Authoring a book is similar to authoring a website.
        P1: Authoring on Facebook is protected by freedom of speech.
        C0: Authoring a website is protected by freedom of speech.

        Nah, I still think it's invalidated by book ≠ Facebook.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        is this argument invalid?
        Post:
        RE: is this argument invalid?
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        24 March 2017 15:14
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        This is how I see it...

        P2: Authoring a book is similar to authoring a website.
        P1: Authoring reviews on Facebook is protected by freedom of speech.
        C0: Authoring a website on how to author reviews is protected by freedom of speech.

        P2 just says book ≈ website; and/or authoring = authoring.
        P1 just says freedom of speech protects authoring opinions.
        C0 just says freedom of speech protects authoring websites (if the website teaches how to author opinions, which P1 says is protected by freedom of speech).

        The conclusion is riding on the idea; authoring about something that is protected, is also protected by the protection (EG it is legal to talk about a legal act, just because the act is legal; NDAs come to mind...); but this is unsupported by the premises (unless authoring in general is protected? P1 may actually be supporting that; I just underlined to word to cross out...).

        I agree, it is an invalid argument.

        The premises are loosely connected...
        Facebook ≠ Defacedbook
        ^Is that even a middle term?!?
        Authoring on Facebook versus authoring a book.

        So maybe it is a valid argument, after all?

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴

        Thread:
        Week 3 - Q2 - Multiple fallacies?
        Post:
        RE: Week 3 - Q2 - Multiple fallacies?
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        23 March 2017 11:14
        Status:
        Published

        Ex4
        L/P = P(L)
        ¬L/P = P(¬L)

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Further Arguments [IU / I / VU / S]
        Post:
        RE: Further Arguments [IU / I / VU / S]
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        23 March 2017 09:29
        Status:
        Published

        Ex2
        … Unsound ∵ S ⇝ U □

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Further Arguments [IU / I / VU / S]
        Post:
        RE: Further Arguments [IU / I / VU / S]
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        23 March 2017 09:26
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Anthony,

        Ex 1
        I ⇝ P
        D → I
        ∴ D ⇝ P
        … Sound ∵ D → I ⇝ P ■ (D=link)

        Ex2
        S → U
        U → W
        ∴ S ↛ W
        … Invalid ∵ S → U → W □
        … Unsound ∵ S → U □
        ∴ Invalid ∧ Unsound ■

        Ex3
        R → S=W
        S=W → A
        ∴ R → A
        … Valid ∵ R → S=W → A □
        … Unsound ∵ S=W ⇝ A □
        ∴ Valid ∧ Unsound ■

        Ex4
        L/P → P(W)
        ¡¬L/P!
        ∴ ¡P(¬W)!
        … Invalid ∵ ¬L/P ¿⇴? P(¬W) □
        … Unsound ∵ L/P ⇝ P(W) ∧ ¿¬L/P? □
        ∴ Invalid ∧ Unsound ■

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        I think the sick student, failing exams, is the red herring; and the bank is pitiful.

        I don't see how being sick prevents someone from studying; unless they're in a coma, or something. Obviously they weren't sick enough for a doctor to postpone their exams; it's a total copout, because being sick had nothing to do with the results of their examination.

        From the banked information, we can say Person A doesn't think Person B shows enough appreciation of them; Person B could then argue, had Person A not been so forgetful, they would have (sarcastically) been gratefully overjoyed! Thus the argument would remain relevant to the discourse at hand.
