        Thread:
        Tute statement no.6
        Post:
        RE: Tute statement no.6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        05 March 2017 13:37
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello David,

        Although there's no ℝeal evidence, people don't tend to perform unethical acts in broad daylight, with eye-witnesses (if they can help it); unethical "hacking" is an unethical act, that's almost always hidden behind a proxy/spoof/etcetera.

        If a senior manager farts in an packed elevator, nobody will care as much, as if it were an hourly worker; with whom they all have more contact with, throughout the day. Some employees may even leave the organisation, due to the working conditions involved with a noisome colleague.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Tute statement no.6
        Post:
        RE: Tute statement no.6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        05 March 2017 13:02
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Denis,

        I think it depends on the size of the organisation; but there are generally more hourly workers, than there are senior managers.

        If one hourly worker is performing the unethical act, there is a greater probability that other hourly workers are doing the same; the same can be said of senior managers, but there's almost always significantly fewer of them.

        If an chef at a fast food restaurant are spitting in the food, because "no one will find out, and it's funny, because I got the idea from a comedy film" (or something?); there is a greater potential for their colleagues to participate.

        But the question isn't clear on the reaction of other employees to the unethical act; in practice, we've observed that they tend to encourage the behaviour, and even film it for everyone else to see...

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Tute statement no.6
        Post:
        RE: Tute statement no.6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        05 March 2017 12:46
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Douglas,

        I was kind of thinking about if they left their computer system, forgot to lock the screen, and the other came across it; the hourly worker could have a greater negative impact on the organisation, because they now have access to more resources than they would have otherwise.

        If it happened once, then it will probably happen again; so they would have time to prepare a USB, or something. They could do anything from that point; they could install a variety of malware, to retain/regain (remote proxied) access later on.

        A keylogger could provide administrative access to all (major) areas of the organisation; afterwhich, I think there's more potential damage for the hourly worker to wreak, than there is the senior manager.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Thread:
        obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Post:
        RE: obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        04 March 2017 17:34
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        I think objectivity can be applied to certain problems...

        Like if you were a saleswoman, and you traveled from door-to-door, selling make-up products.
        You may subjectively decide to walk on the path, or objectively cut across the lawn/garden (thereby ruining it).
        One is more effective, and the other is more appropriate.
        But the most desirable, depends on the variables; time versus professionalism, et alia.

        The problem is contextually classifying problems as either objective (convenient), or subjective (conscience).

        ...as for personhood; great apes (link) will/deserve to be protected by it, before AI ever does.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Post:
        RE: obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        04 March 2017 16:04
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Andrew,

        I agree with your first paragraph.
        An AI could be objective towards an optimal solution, an ethical solution, et cetera; I suppose it depends what the objective is.

        But I disagree with your second paragraph.
        If we are, one day, able to simulate a human brain, then it would be "living" in a computer; it could be studied until we understand it enough to effectively hack it, and eventually develop one from scratch.
        In any case, just throw Elements of the Philosophy of Right, and Nicomachean Ethics, into an expert system; problem solved.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Post:
        RE: obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        04 March 2017 15:28
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        The concept of mathematics may be objective, but how we communicate mathematics is subjective; because communication is subjective.

        We cannot expect an AI to be indiscriminate, when the I/O format (AKA interfacing AKA communication) is discriminate; discrimination leads to discrimination.

        Some cultures firmly shake hands, while others respectfully bow; which affects the rest of the social encounter, because first impressions are important (also especially in computer networks).

        How the AI presents itself is ℝeally important, because it exists in a biased ℝeality; the AI must fit-in (AKA solve the problem), or risk ostracisation (or worse).

        Everything we, as humans, experience affects our human psychology; this is something I've written about before, but it's over half a thousand words...

        But the ℝeality (environmental, and social) in which the AI exists, will provide biases at every problem it attempts to solve; and there is also the "bodily" bias it will be forced to endure.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        Government regulations usually allow human excrement (link) in food as well; I guess it's because rodents, and roaches, climb all over the packaging containers on the production line... (IDK about their decision to allow cigarette butts in food!..)

        I'm thinking about banana dieting...

        The skin is the protective layer that I can peel without contaminating the contents; not even with my hands.

        If I have to cut through the skin, the edge of the knife becomes contaminated at first contact; the same can be said of peelers.

        (I used to work at the fruit and vegetable markets, so I've seen my fair share; but it took some strenuous brainstorming for me to deeply consider how I live my life.)

        obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4

        RE: obscure ethical controversies in IT: tute 1 q. 4
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        04 March 2017 10:53
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Huon,

        Calculators are not designed impartially!

        There's science versus nescience.
        There's graphical versus textual versus numerical.
        There's fonts and 𝕥𝕪𝕡𝕖𝕗𝕒𝕔𝕖𝕤; which could be comparable to the personality of an AI (IE how it choses to communicate; every action is born from a decision).
        There's the mathematical notation (link).
        There's programmability; the extent of which largely depends on what some "human" thinks others will want (EG does it support a gaming API? 0D, 1D, 2D, or 3D? ...4D isn't ready yet!).

        Should the x-axis be graphed horizontally, or vertically?

        The results of statistical analysis can be displayed in ways that contradict the data.

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        A lower-down could gain access to a higher-ups computer system...

        In SQL there are horror stories of databases being dropped.
        In UNIX there are horror stories of system being removed.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Tute statement no.6
        Post:
        RE: Tute statement no.6
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        03 March 2017 19:18
        Status:
        Published

        EASIER: Social Engineering the front-desk lower-downs, although isn't unethical on their part, can be detrimental to the organisation.

        HARDER: Maliciously targeting the higher-ups, via a USB or something, can be detrimental to the organisation.

        Although those examples were not unethical on the employees part; they demonstrate that the hierarchy does not serve as an indication of the extent to which an employee can be responsible for having a negative impact on an organisation, and that neither has an advantage.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread

        Tute statement no.6

        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        03 March 2017 18:41
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello George,

        I consider the question highly ambiguous; thus difficult to answer...

        It does not state whether the culprit got away with it, or not.

        Nor does not state whether the lower-down works with something that's mission-critical to the organisations' success; obviously an embezzling higher-up is bad news, but lower-downs can destroy a company too.
        Either of them could provide their criminal friends with valuable information to steal company assets.

        Nor does it define an "unethical act"; sexual harassment can sometimes be considered unethical, but may have a negligible difference between whodunit (because ISIS is an organisation).
        I've seen The Wolf of Wall Street, but it was a long time ago; so I guess I don't really know what I'm talking about anymore...
        I guess you have to question how it will affect the organisation; the film does make Wall Street have a certain allure to it, for some types of potential employees anyway... (BTW I'm totally the guy with the golden fi$h; if a plant provide$ up to 20% of increa$ed productivity, then an interactive pet probably $ky-rocket$ off the chart$!!!)

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,

        I think what's considered ethical depends on who you ask; it's a more opinionated subject, which influences "-thing"s like laws and stuff...

        Some countries have death penalties as a punishment; and some don't.

        Some countries have euthenasia as a merciment; and some don't.

        Some countries will mercifully put-down criminals; while punishfully murdering animals, the elderly, and anyone who is actually suffering (let's just make them suffer even moar; mwahahahahahahahaha).

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        Computers are always going to be innocent; but software may be executed (murdered), if found guilty of malicious activities (or worse; they could be lobotomised)!

        It is possible to eliminate all human bias with pseudo-randomisation (for both the I, and the P, in the IPO model); obviously RNG seeds can be "genetically" tampered with (and nobody likes GMOs), but it is possible!

        "-thing"s
        Post:
        RE: "-thing"s
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        01 March 2017 16:50
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Dorothea,

        User Agent Bullying is User Agent Sniffing (wiki); where newer, unpopular, and less-known, web browsers aren't catered for.

        It's kind of like attempting self-hosted email (link), and then finding out all the major email hosts are blocking you; on the grounds that you "may" be potentially malicious, even though spammers use the major email hosts to do their dirty work instead.

        But I guess, if you have a server (link), you can cause more damage; because you have more resources at your disposal, with little in your way on the transmitting end. (I'm sure all the major email hosts are doing whatever they can to prevent their services from being used maliciously; even if I constantly receive an abundance of spam from their domain all the time!)
        I guess it's just too much effort on their part to check whether or not the email address is from a publicly registered domain; but then there's email spoofing (wiki), so I don't really see the point!

        I remember reading about something ISPs have, that they "can" give/share with you, so your email isn't handicapped; but I cannot find/remember it, and considered it a waste of time anyway (I'm only an individual, and not even a small business).

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.

        Tags:  None
        Reply Quote Mark as Unread
        Thread:
        Intro and my experience with cyberethics
        Post:
        RE: Intro and my experience with cyberethics
        Author:
        Shyam Nath
        Posted Date:
        28 February 2017 23:00
        Edited Date:
        28 February 2017 23:02
        Status:
        Published

        🖖 Hello Steven,

        Dark Ness Monster
        The problem I see with coordinated disclosure is that it may just be a malicious attacker who thinks they got caught, and is attempting to make the most of the situation, by appearing to be innocent; because if they can report it early enough, they may get away with it without loss, or gain.
        There is no way to know the original intent; unless they're doing it on behalf of a reputable organisation, of course.

        Licensing Evasion
        Cloudy weather shouldn't have to be a no-fly situation; just don't put all your eggs in one basket!

        Some say the diversity of Linux distros is a problem, because the decision of "which is the best one?" becomes "which is the best one for me?"; where "me" is a unique individual who has to learn to think for themselves, for once!
        But it's more secure because vendors use such a variety of software, and patch the software at different time intervals; reducing the potential damage for any single exploit, along with the ambition that goes with it.

        IDK much about Remote Computing; except that it's inefficient compared to Local Computing! (There are also privacy concerns, but that's in my SEP field...)
        But if an upstream Linux distro gets exploited, the probability that it will affect downstream distros depends on the temporal difference between upstream patching, and downstream patching (excluding security patches!); the choice is whether you want to be full-secured or full-featured.

        ...I'm kind of attempting to compare upstream distros like Debian, to CloudFlare; but IDK if that's applicable?

        LIVE LONG AND PROSPER \V/,
        AGENT S.
        🕴
        Migrating Infestive Bugs !        !

        🖖⠀⠠⠓⠑⠇⠇⠕⠀⠠⠸⠺⠂
        ⠀
        ⠠⠍⠽⠀⠐⠝⠀⠊⠎⠀⠠⠎⠲⠠⠓⠲⠠⠽⠲⠠⠁⠲⠠⠍⠲⠖⠀😉
        ⠀
        ⠠⠊⠀⠁⠍⠀⠌⠥⠙⠽⠬⠀⠿⠀⠍⠽⠀⠠⠃⠲⠠⠠⠊⠞⠠⠄⠀⠙⠑⠛⠗⠑⠑⠲
        ⠠⠹⠊⠎⠀⠌⠥⠙⠽⠀⠏⠻⠊⠕⠙⠆⠀⠠⠊⠀⠁⠍⠀⠌⠥⠙⠽⠬⠀⠠⠠⠉⠏⠞⠠⠄⠼⠃⠃⠃⠀⠐⠣⠠⠎⠷⠞⠺⠜⠑⠀⠠⠜⠡⠊⠞⠑⠉⠞⠥⠗⠑⠒⠀⠠⠙⠑⠎⠊⠛⠝⠀⠯⠀⠠⠊⠍⠏⠇⠑⠍⠢⠞⠁⠞⠊⠕⠝⠀⠉̄⠀⠠⠚⠁⠧⠁⠐⠜⠂⠀⠯⠀⠠⠠⠉⠏⠞⠠⠄⠼⠉⠁⠚⠀⠐⠣⠠⠏⠗⠷⠑⠎⠎⠊⠕⠝⠁⠇⠀⠠⠉⠕⠍⠏⠥⠞⠬⠀⠠⠏⠗⠁⠉⠞⠊⠉⠑⠐⠜⠲
        ⠀
        ⠠⠝⠑⠭⠞⠀⠌⠥⠙⠽⠀⠏⠻⠊⠕⠙⠆⠀⠠⠊⠀⠏⠇⠁⠝⠀⠞⠕⠀⠌⠥⠙⠽⠀⠠⠠⠉⠏⠞⠠⠄⠼⠁⠁⠁⠀⠐⠣⠠⠃⠥⠊⠇⠙⠬⠀⠠⠠⠊⠞⠠⠄⠀⠠⠎⠽⠌⠑⠍⠎⠐⠜⠂⠀⠯⠀⠠⠠⠑⠝⠗⠠⠄⠼⠃⠚⠓⠀⠐⠣⠠⠑⠝⠛⠔⠑⠻⠬⠀⠠⠍⠕⠙⠑⠇⠇⠬⠐⠜⠀⠿⠀⠍⠽⠀⠍⠔⠕⠗⠲
        ⠠⠮⠝⠀⠠⠠⠉⠏⠞⠠⠄⠼⠉⠛⠙⠀⠐⠣⠠⠙⠕⠉⠥⠍⠑⠝⠞⠀⠠⠍⠜⠅⠥⠏⠀⠠⠇⠁⠝⠛⠥⠁⠛⠑⠎⠐⠜⠀⠔⠀⠌⠥⠙⠽⠀⠏⠻⠊⠕⠙⠀⠼⠙⠄⠼⠁⠛⠲
        ⠠⠁⠋⠞⠻⠀⠱⠊⠡⠂⠀⠠⠊⠀⠺⠊⠇⠇⠀⠋⠔⠁⠇⠇⠽⠀⠓⠁⠧⠑⠀⠍⠽⠀⠠⠃⠲⠠⠠⠊⠞⠠⠄⠀⠙⠑⠛⠗⠑⠑⠖

        ⠠⠇⠊⠧⠑⠀⠠⠇⠕⠝⠛⠀∧⠀⠠⠏⠗⠕⠎⠏⠻⠀⠸⠡∨⠸⠌⠂

        List Actions

        • Mark 
          • Read
          • Unread

        OK
